And as loathe as I'd be to get bogged down in discourse here, I'll venture 
a starter on what this abysmal effort conveys a struggle to grasp.

Sommers refers to the gamer ratios? Why would she do this? Firstly to 
illustrate the feminist propensity for distorting the truth to fit the 
agenda. 
They model their numbers with careful exclusions. When in the hard-core 
gamer arena, women are far from the majority. And the more hard-core you 
get (MLG, Lan-fest) the fewer there are.
The reference to female dominated talk shows is not a false equivalent, 
prat. It's an apt reference to a social segment that is mostly catering to 
one gender. And it's a relevant counterpoint to pose. 
Well? Why do all these shows have to be so geared towards women? Well uh, 
they're serving the market that is serving it. Ner? Which brings us back 
again to the relevance of the gamer ratio. 
The people lining the pockets the most are male gamers. And they are 
cheaply catering to that crowd. And they're entitled to. Should we cover 
that word more carefully? You, you want more choice. 
That's sweet. You want more choice. But you're not entitled to it. If they 
provide it, great. But they're not obligated to provide it. Now, before you 
get carried away like I know you like to and think [Well, I never said 
that, it would just be nice]. Perhaps it would, but your choice of words 
smacks of petulance. "I"."I want more choice". The market isn't driven by 
what YOU want. However brilliant you think your thoughts are on the 
subject. Sarkeesian chalks everything up to sexism, with no regard to the 
counterpoint that contextualizes whether it is actually sexism. 

"Most AAA Games are full of sexist tropes". Well uh, that would be the part 
we're disputing, turbo. Or, would you like to make your case based on 
Sarkeesian's videos?

How about I go you one better. I'm fed up with games, not on the level of 
being sexist. Just for being bad. Lazy writers use proven formulas to make 
and sell games. 

OH GOSH! A few naughty nutters said some nasty things on TWITTER! 
Sarkeesian insulting an entire group through generalization, which makes 
the more reactive ones bite back. But it's sexism! Except when it happens 
to men. Because Jack Thompson in Mortal Kombat was all about male-bashing. 
Speaking of violence, it's perplexing that you'd bemoan the conflation 
between violence and misogyny. Since she's addressing something in the 
terms it was presented to her, by Sarkeesian; who apparently perceives them 
welded like a parasite to a pooch.
 

P.S. Your musics almost as dodgy as Sarkeesian's tropes videos. Keep making 
it.﻿

Guess what? Ta-da. A study came out that showed there was no link between 
video games and sexism, a full-blown 3 year long longitudal study. How does

+sinistar99 that phrase only states in terms that even you can understand 
that there *might* be a study somewhere where a person *might* have a link, 
either direct or indirect regarding sexual objectification and video games. 
It's theoretically possible that Barack Obama may send a picture of his 
junk to the New York Times, but he won't do that and it's theoretically 
possible that a video game might cause someone to become more sexist, but 
that's wrong too, because all you have to do is look at a little thing 
called common sense. 

Millennials, those born after 1980, are less sexist than Generation X and 
they have been immersed in video game culture, which is now a $20 billion 
per year industry. Generation X, born between 1965 and 1980 are less sexist 
than Baby Boomers, and they also play video games. If there was a link 
between video games and sexism, the amount of sexism in culture would be 
out of control, it wouldn't be going down every generation. 

This is a case of history repeating itself. In 1999, the same assholes who 
whine and bitch like worthless cunts about sexism in video games tried to 
prove a direct link between violent video games and people going on a 
rampage and killing people in real life. Four years later, the Supreme 
Court ruled no link was possible between the two, and the same thing is 
bound to happen with sexism. The same moral panic happened in the 1980s 
when whiny cunts tried to prove a causal link between heavy metal and 
suicide, and what they found was that the people who listened to heavy 
metal and committed suicide would have committed suicide regardless of 
whether or not they listen to heavy metal. The same thing is happening 
here. In other words, already sexist people might become more sexist if 
they play video games. Wow, that's news. They also might be more sexist 
while watching porn or 2 Broke Girls. 

Every single study that you have quoted was done for 1 month or less, in 
other words, short term. The study I quoted was over 3 years, 36 times 
longer and in that study, they found no causal link between video games and 
sexist attitudes. It also had nearly 3 times as many participants, which 
means the survey size was considerably larger. 

The only thing you've proven is that people who are inclined to be sexist 
will be sexist by playing video games. If you look at the most sexist 
people in the world, I'm sure that all the members of ISIS all love their 
Playstation 4s. Oh wait, that's right. They don't play video games. How 
about the gangsta rappers? Oh wait, they don't really play that much. If 
they did play, it wouldn't affect much of their attitudes, because they 
were already raised in a household and had sexism promoted by rap culture. 

Sexism is a function of age and education, not the ability of playing video 
games. Someone who is older will be more sexist and those who have less 
than a high school education will also be more sexist. 

Translation: Suck a fat chode, suck it long, suck it hard. The only people 
who will be sexist after playing video games would be sexist regardless of 
whether or not they play video games. I'm sorry you're a pathetic loser who 
can't read further into studies, but one day you might evolve enough to 
understand this. If Darwin is right, it will be about 5,000,000 years from 
now.

+SRHinckley Haha Here's another quote from that same study you might have

"As indicated by the limitations of the present study and the tentative

‘some genres/games have some [cultivation] effects on some players.’

+sinistar99 "From the oversexualized characters in fighting games, such as 
Dead or 
Alive or Ninja Gaiden, to the overuse of the damsel in distress trope in
popular titles, such as the Super Mario series, the under- and 
misrepresentation of females in video games has been well documented in 
several content analyses. Cultivation theory suggests that long-term 
exposure to media content can affect perceptions of social realities in a
way that they become more similar to the representations in the media 
and, in turn, impact one's beliefs and attitudes. Previous studies on 
video games and cultivation have often been cross-sectional or 
experimental, and the limited longitudinal work in this area has only 
considered time intervals of up to 1 month. Additionally, previous work 
in this area has focused on the effects of violent content and relied on
self-selected or convenience samples composed mostly of adolescents or 
college students. Enlisting a 3 year longitudinal design, the present 
study assessed the relationship between video game use and sexist 
attitudes, using data from a representative sample of German players 
aged 14 and older (N=824). Controlling for age and education, it was 
found that sexist attitudes--measured with a brief scale assessing 
beliefs about gender roles in society--were not related to the amount of
daily video game use or preference for specific genres for both female 
and male players. Implications for research on sexism in video games and
cultivation effects of video games in general are discussed."

Abstract of study done 18 April 2015

+Silverizael
There were two more studies that were somewhat relevant that she linked to. 
They're about the social construct of online video games. Again, it's not 
evidence that the games themselves perpetuate misogynism and sexism, but 
that it happens in these environments. As we can already tell, it's very 
likely that many sexist individuals play games like CoD, so of course those 
environments are going to be toxic. One was about sexism in online video 
games, the other was about the behavior of women who played games and then 
chose to dress their character in a sexy manner. I have only just skimmed 
through them but it seems that the first one found that sexism was 
prevalent and the second one found that women who dressed their characters 
in sexy outfits were more likely to wear sexy outfits themselves and were 
also more likely to be accepting of rape myth. It's interesting because it 
relates to the Proteus Effect which is basically that while you're under a 
certain identity online, you will think like that identity and you will 
behave like it too. It's basically that we all have different opinions 
depending on whether or not we're fully anonymous or not. If this means 
that the women will then go on with their lives and be more accepting to 
rape myth is another question entirely. What they have shown is that if you 
sexualize and objectify yourself, you're going to start thinking of 
yourself like a sexualized object.

This is all very interesting, but nothing is conclusive and there's just 
too little data to make any sweeping statements. Anita is not using the 
right methods to get her points across. What we know is that there is some 
sexism, that mirrors society, in games but we don't properly know how this 
actually affects the gamers. If she had made a video about the Proteus 
Effect and discussed its effects on people then I would've been fine with 
it. But atm she's lying to our faces when she says everything like it's the 
truth. I get ya man. We all want more interesting game characters and we 
all want powerful women in our gaming, but Anita is not the way.

Anyhow, this study asked the participants to read a story where a man 
sexually harasses a woman. Interestingly, men who had seen women, in 
photos, wearing sexual outfits were more accepting to the harassment than 
the control group, while women who were exposed to the same material were 
less accepting than the control group. What's even more interesting is that 
the people who played many hours a week of violent video games were even 
less inclined to have negative reactions to the sexual harassment. But! 
This only applied to gamers who played lots of violent video games. It begs 
the question. Is this causation or correlation? We all know what types of 
guys play CoD for example. Those types of games may be drawing that kind of 
attention.

On the subject of whether or not it's conclusive, here is a quote from the 
study:

Although more complex models did not indicate significant effects of 
long-term exposure to video game violence, simpler correlational analyses 
did reveal significant relationships between long-term violent video game 
exposure and less progressive sexual harassment judgments and greater rape 
supportive attitudes. These correlations are similar to those reported in 
earlier research (Dill, 2008). It may be that the checklist measure of 
long-term video game violence exposure used here is a weaker measure than 
the game-listing version used in a variety of other investigations. 
Furthermore, there is a difference between the still images used in the 
experimental manipulation and the live action game content that the 
long-term measure represents. While these results add to the very small 
literature correlating long-term exposure to video game violence with 
attitudes supporting violence against women, more research is needed to 
elucidate these relationships.

I might have nerded out a bit too much on this. But the researchers said

any causation involved. They say themselves that more research is needed.

Anita is calling for no such ban. No one I know of is calling for a ban on 
games that contain sexist tropes. No one. 

In fact, Anita says, "You can enjoy these games and still be critical of 
some of their more problematic aspects."

So, for instance, I think Rockstar games are amazing. I think the sexist 
tropes they contain are harmful and stupid. I don't think any video game 
should be banned. Easy peasy. 

Hence, the debate around sexism and violence are inherently different. 
That's why conflating the two issues was disingenuous. 
2. Tropes by definition limit choice: They're the same thing over and over. 
More of the same tropes = more of the same shit. Less tropes = more choice. 
Less tropes does not mean no tropes. 

Less tropes = There's still some tropes + but there's also everything else.

3. What Anita actually says is that sexist video games reinforce harmful 
myths about women. This is very, very, very much not the same as saying 
video games cause sexism. 

But since you brought it up, here's 6 studies that show that playing games 
with sexist tropes negatively effects views of women: 

http://psychology.okstate.edu/faculty/mburkley/Melissa_Burkley,_Ph.D._Social_Cognition_Lab/Publications_files/PPMC.pdf
http://psychology.okstate.edu/faculty/mburkley/Melissa_Burkley,_Ph.D._Social_Cognition_Lab/Publications_files/PPMC.pdf
http://www.academia.edu/1865189/The_Effects_of_the_Sexualization_of_Female_Video_Game_Characters_on_Gender_Stereotyping_and_Female_Self-Concept
http://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s11199-009-9695-4/fulltext.html
http://vhil.stanford.edu/pubs/2009/fox-sr-virgins-vamps.pdf
http://my.psychologytoday.com/files/attachments/30298/dill-et-al-jesp-2008.pdf

4. Christina's video was glib and disingenuous, and so I treated it as 
such.

To all those ranting and hating, let me just say this: this is not a 
personal attack on you. This is not an attack on you as a group. This is 
not saying that if you're a male gamer you are a misogynist and a bigot, it 
is not saying any of these things.

It is saying that there is a problem. Not in all games, not with all gamers 
- hell, not even with the majority - but it is a problem that is there and 
is too big to be ignored, because the people who do act like misogynists 
are very, very loud and vocal and make life seriously unpleasant for a 
whole section of our community. And some games (and the attitudes of some 
gaming studios) reinforces these attitudes.

And one more thing. Whether you agree or disagree, please think about how 
you respond. Think about it like this: if someone from outside the 
community saw the comments on this page, what would they think about you? 
If your message is "we're not misogynists aresholes" but the you express 
this with threats and anger and words like "mangina", which message comes 
across most strongly?﻿

Step one in an argument may be to suppose flaws in your opponent's, but it 
stops there when this only amounts to saying, "huh?" and you've done no 
research of your own. The other thing it can amount to is cherry-picking. 
Take the next step, and realize beyond this attempt at humor, that examples 
are out there throughout gaming (or all) history where things are quite 
different than the feminist narrative. False equivalencies pointed out in 
Sommers' video, for example, aren't of her own making, but directly 
addressing the ones "feminism" often hides behind as a movement -- it's 
they who often put what you call unlike things together, some even going so 
far to claim misogyny *is* violence, that emotional attack *is* "emotional" 
violence, that sex is violence by its very nature (i.e. Dworkin's response 
to the Marquis De Sade art style), now applied to pop culture as a whole; 
feminist claims, all, so should they not be addressed directly? -- along 
with manipulated statistics and emotional subversion? On more direct lines, 
too, pointing out how roundly the violence in games debate fell apart under 
real-world conditions offers a solid correlation and note of comparison to 
sexism in games, if taking the stance they are systematized and 
institutional. As does the patriarchy, institutional misogyny, and so on... 
It doesn't help the general confusion when the person in question, for this 
video response, is herself a feminist from an earlier phase of its 
progression, who's not only seen the folly in it as time goes on, but 
witnessed these same contentions being used repeatedly to gain footholds 
into people's thought-processes. It's done in the manner of idealogues 
falling to utter lunacy, paranoia, and hidden agenda, rather than for the 
sake of cogent argument and *actual* justice. If even a shred of merit 
could be found behind why she'd come to that perspective, a refutation in 
this style doesn't much add to the discussion she raises, and seems only 
designed for speaking to and/or validating the already established thoughts 
of said idealogues. 

There's even an equally funny rebuttal done as a song simply refuting this 
fundamental claim of low/poor representation in gaming, by way of actually 
listing, illustrating, and describing the history of why there is a 
contrary viewpoint with undeniable examples -- some of them boldly fly in 
the face of claims made on Feminist Frequency, in fact, as if thinking no 
one would bother to just look through a catalogue of influential game 
characters against how they were being portrayed under some sexist 
microscope... she's like a sexism-seeking missile, except in light of such 
facts, seems to have a been miscalibrated somehow. She's seen it where it 
is not; profited from non-thought; escalated detraction from anger to rage 
then claimed victimization, all with a focus on outliers and those who'd be 
sick under any arrangement. Sommers was being very broad in carrying out an 
introductory discussion from an outsider's perspective, instead. Go 
further. It gets beyond Anita. Literally nothing Anita says is objectively, 
quantifiably true... upon reflection, with her patterns of blatant 
dishonesty clear to anyone who cares about the nature of truth (where a 
liar often wraps things in true-seeming points to cover a malicious 
agenda), and in her appealing what amounts to only a very individualistic, 
subjective, emotionally rather than fact-driven argument, her's is a 
pattern often repeated throughout the hard-line of feminism -- who, mind 
you, can be just a vile, hateful, mean-spirited, shaming, and violence 
prone as any other types; also, such examples show nothing unusual (because 
all humans are predatory animals built with deep-seated energies made for 
hunting and opportunism), released in arguably unhealthy/unproductive ways 
through these new mediums we're still trying to work out in our shared 
society. You may not personally have ever been a victim of female on male 
violence, harassment, sexual abuse, bullying, etc., at least on your own 
terms or any combination not considered the understood and accepted norms 
(as if a norm equals only; as if unclear equals unreal), but many of us 
have, some look this mindless, un-empathetic downplaying of such things 
right in the face whenever they are presented in blanketed and absolutist 
fashion, and many more of us are quite capable of sifting through examples 
or stats taken in aggregate and out of context for the sheer purposes of 
manipulation, control, and taking through unjust means; something 
reflective of an abusive relationship, itself, in fact, as a mentality, 
except in this case on a societal scale.

It isn't easy, thinking and searching, but can't/shouldn't just be handed 
away, seen lightly, or taken in stride if unwilling to leave a chosen or 
immediate comfort zone -- if recognition doesn't extend beyond the self, or 
the alike to self. For a changing era involving all sorts of shifting 
dynamics to human nature, it's not a flag to hold up when the worst aspects 
of us come into direct conflict without aim, understanding, or release, but 
a symptom, and one that I think is being wholly misunderstood and 
de-contextualized using a founding principle lacking reason or wisdom, here 
-- it's that "shifting goal-post," selfish emotional plea speaking to 
selfishness, hold up the least common denominator to distract from internal 
flaws in the original, suppress dissent, shame detractors in-kind, slip in 
ideological constructs to actually steal more power and influence while 
others aren't looking, thing, exactly -- all this amounts to is the 
textbook of feminist debate, where just beneath the surface is a sea of 
larger falsehoods, half-truths, and twisting of whatever's left; "new boss 
same as the old boss" in a struggle for power and control where everyone 
ultimately loses. If you start searching, you'll probably find arguments 
that are invalid to sort through, all over, but by now many of the ones 
with actual legwork behind them should be fairly known and attainable... 
some of the most compelling seem to indicate there is a greater pattern to 
these flaws, of which even feminists are victims of through the strange 
mental processes behind its philosophy. If they are categorically victims 
of anything, in the end, it is themselves.

Luckily, "nothing is a pure edifice..." and any conscious point of view is 
worth its chance for expression, but our internal and external 
reevaluations should never cease. When they do, new thought could take a 
jump-start and a couple of shocks to get going again. To me, it's as simple 
as that, like the "isms" of painting where the greatest are those who not 
only can apply the brush with skill, but have the eye to know when to stop, 
which many must practice to learn innately and many more must have a 
second, conflicting voice to ever understand. 

That's why she makes a focal point, because she acts as a case-study. 
That's why she's fuel for the anger of the less articulate, whether 
verbally or emotionally. That's why -- the examples almost too endless to 
count -- she's seen as a blatant con-artist, both financially and as one 
pushing an errant, destructive, thought-manipulating agenda. Is she a 
puppet? Is she a figurehead? Who can say... what seems clear, is that no 
faction of a cause in history has genuinely benefited from brushing off and 
smashing its counter-points or critiques over the long-term, something all 
sides could certainly learn from in this and many other issues; but the 
arguments and example *are* out there to be weighed, processed, and 
internalized into a critically thought-out decision of choice. We, no one, 
shows wisdom with a shrug and a laugh toward the disagreeable and not 
self-matching point of view, but especially toward what could be objective 
evidence that is measurable, tangible, and unflinching against scrutiny -- 
it just demands real scrutiny, which this is not. The false statistics 
often used elsewhere are not, because in the reverse they don't stand, but 
neither does a break-down of semantics that amount to nothing. Deeper 
investigation holds up on the side against Anita, and it falls apart almost 
immediately on the side for her, for feminism, and beyond; except for where 
actual dishonesty and appeals of feeling have turned supporters into 
zealots not even desiring any truth which opposes them. Indeed, feminism 
seems more like a religion than a movement, in that regard. Never follow a 
herd for the sheer sake of belonging, image, and "looking good" or 
righteous on your surface as a person. Fitting in's not worth it. Be 
adaptable, and ready to change. This advice goes out to all true 
individuals.  

I don't think there's a "bad guy" in everything to do with life, if good 
and bad's even really understandable beyond our singular and transitory 
experiences... even you... but finding this, I must say, I think it's 
Sommers who's just won my subscription and support. At the very least, 
though I can rightly say I've never seen anyone who I fully agree with on 
all subjects, she seems well-meaning. I'll be looking forward to browsing 
old discussions, and seeing what else she brings to the table, in future. ﻿

MESSAGE.  It's against their MO.  It's against their methods of how they 
get the message OUT.  And in an oddly circular sense, the criticism about 
them not being able to take criticism is probably the biggest beast to 
tackle.

Below are 4 more studies that back up my claim (making 8/14 altogether).

“Violent Video Games, Delinquency and Youth Violence: New Evidence”
DeLisi, Matt; Vaughn, Michael G.; Gentile, Douglas A.; Anderson, Craig A.; 
Shook, Jeffrey J. Youth Violence and Juvenile Justice, April 2013, Vol. 11, 
No. 2. doi: 10.1177/1541204012460874.

“Based on a data from a sample of institutionalized juvenile delinquents, 
behavioral and attitudinal measures relating to violent video game playing 
were associated with a composite measure of delinquency and a more specific 
measure of violent delinquency after controlling for the effects of screen 
time, years playing video games, age, sex, race, delinquency history and 
psychopathic personality traits. Violent video games are associated with 
antisociality even in a clinical sample, and these effects withstand the 
robust influences of multiple correlates of juvenile delinquency and youth 
violence most notably psychopathy.”

- See more at: 
http://journalistsresource.org/studies/government/criminal-justice/value-violent-video-games-research-roundup#sthash.pUZaQJOL.myhtI8Wz.dpuf

“Identification Matters: A Moderated Mediation Model of Media 
Interactivity, Character Identification and Video Game Violence on 
Aggression”
Lin, Jih-Hsuan. Journal of Communication, June 2013. doi: 
10.1111/jcom.12044.

Abstract: “This study examined the effects of interactivity in violent 
video games on aggression and tested identification as the moderated 
mediating mechanism. A total of 169 male undergraduate students 
participated in a 2 media interactivity (enactive mediation vs. 
observational mediation) × 2 violence (violent vs. nonviolent) experiment. 
Results supported a moderated mediation model in which the effect of media 
interactivity on aggressive affect through identification was moderated by 
violence. When violence was present, interactive play resulted in higher 
short-term aggressive affect through higher character identification than 
when violence was not present. Additionally, an interaction effect between 
media interactivity and violence was found for automatic self-concept in 
which players associated themselves more with the game character’s traits 
than video viewers.”

- See more at: 
http://journalistsresource.org/studies/government/criminal-justice/value-violent-video-games-research-roundup#sthash.pUZaQJOL.myhtI8Wz.dpuf

“Violent and Nonviolent Video Games Differentially Affect Physical 
Aggression for Individuals High vs. Low in Dispositional Anger”
Engelhardt, Christopher R.; Bartholow, Bruce D.; Saults, J. Scott. 
Aggressive Behavior, November/December 2011, Vol. 37(6), 539-546.

Abstract: “Although numerous experiments have shown that exposure to 
violent video games (VVG) causes increases in aggression, relatively few 
studies have investigated the extent to which this effect differs as a 
function of theoretically relevant individual difference factors. This 
study investigated whether video game content differentially influences 
aggression as a function of individual differences in trait anger. 
Participants were randomly assigned to play a violent or nonviolent video 
game before completing a task in which they could behave aggressively. 
Results showed that participants high in trait anger were the most 
aggressive, but only if they first played a VVG. This relationship held 
while statistically controlling for dimensions other than violent content 
on which game conditions differed (e.g. frustration, arousal). Implications 
of these findings for models explaining the effects of video games on 
behavior are discussed.”

- See more at: 
http://journalistsresource.org/studies/government/criminal-justice/value-violent-video-games-research-roundup#sthash.pUZaQJOL.myhtI8Wz.dpuf

“Causal Effects of Violent Sports Video Games on Aggression: Is It 
Competitiveness or Violent Content?”
Anderson, Craig A.; Carnageya, Nicholas L. Journal of Experimental Social 
Psychology, July 2009, Vol. 45(4), 731-739.

Abstract: “Three experiments examined the impact of excessive violence in 
sport video games on aggression-related variables. Participants played 
either a nonviolent simulation-based sports video game (baseball or 
football) or a matched excessively violent sports video game. Participants 
then completed measures assessing aggressive cognitions (Experiment 1), 
aggressive affect and attitudes towards violence in sports (Experiment 2), 
or aggressive behavior (Experiment 3). Playing an excessively violent 
sports video game increased aggressive affect, aggressive cognition, 
aggressive behavior, and attitudes towards violence in sports. Because all 
games were competitive, these findings indicate that violent content 
uniquely leads to increases in several aggression-related variables, as 
predicted by the General Aggression Model and related social-cognitive 
models.”

- See more at: 
http://journalistsresource.org/studies/government/criminal-justice/value-violent-video-games-research-roundup#sthash.HcmvNmvW.dpuf

+Derek Halder Read it this time, because your comment seems to assume it 
doesn't exist:
“‘Boom, Headshot!’ Effect of Video Game Play and Controller Type on Firing 
Aim and Accuracy” Whitaker, Jodi L.; Bushman, Brad J. Communication 
Research, April 2012.
Abstract: “Video games are excellent training tools. Some writers have 
called violent video games “murder simulators.” Can violent games “train” a 
person to shoot a gun? There are theoretical reasons to believe they can. 
Participants (N = 151) played a violent shooting game with humanoid targets 
that rewarded headshots, a nonviolent shooting game with bull’s-eye 
targets, or a nonviolent nonshooting game. Those who played a shooting game 
used either a pistol-shaped or a standard controller. Next, participants 
shot a realistic gun at a mannequin. Participants who played a violent 
shooting game using a pistol-shaped controller had 99% more headshots and 
33% more other shots than did other participants. These results remained 
significant even after controlling for firearm experience, gun attitudes, 
habitual exposure to violent shooting games, and trait aggressiveness. 
Habitual exposure to violent shooting games also predicted shooting 
accuracy. Thus, playing violent shooting video games can improve firing 
accuracy and can influence players to aim for the head.”
- See more at: 
http://journalistsresource.org/studies/government/criminal-justice/value-violent-video-games-research-roundup#sthash.pUZaQJOL.dpuf
- 
“Violent Video Games Cause an Increase in Aggression Long After the Game 
Has Been Turned Off” Bushman, Brad J.; Gibson, Bryan. Social Psychological 
and Personality Science, January 2011, Vol. 2(1), 29-32.
Abstract: “Experimental studies show that violent video games cause people 
to behave more aggressively, but how long does the effect last? In most 
experiments, aggression is measured immediately after gameplay. The present 
experiment is the first to test the long-term causal effects of violent 
video games on aggression. By the flip of a coin, participants played a 
violent or nonviolent game for 20 min. Within each group, half ruminated 
about the game. The next day, participants competed with an ostensible 
opponent on a competitive task in which the winner could punish the loser 
with painful noise blasts through headphones. Results showed that violent 
video games increased aggression 24 hr later, but only among men who 
ruminated about the game. Rumination keeps aggressive thoughts, feelings, 
and behavioral tendencies active. If players ruminate about the violence in 
a game, the aggression-stimulating effects of the game persist long after 
it has been turned off.”
- See more at: 
http://journalistsresource.org/studies/government/criminal-justice/value-violent-video-games-research-roundup#sthash.pUZaQJOL.dpuf

“Longitudinal Effects of Violent Video Games on Aggression in Japan and the 
United States” Anderson, Craig A.; Sakamoto, Akira; Gentile, Douglas A.; 
Ihori, Nobuko; Shibuya, Akiko; Yukawa, Shintaro; Naito, Mayumi; Kobayashi, 
Kumiko. Pediatrics, November 2008, Vol. 122(5), e1067-e1072.
Abstract: “We tested whether high exposure to violent video games increases 
physical aggression over time in both high- (United States) and low- 
(Japan) violence cultures. We hypothesized that the amount of exposure to 
violent video games early in a school year would predict changes in 
physical aggressiveness assessed later in the school year, even after 
statistically controlling for gender and previous physical aggressiveness…. 
Habitual violent video game play early in the school year predicted later 
aggression, even after controlling for gender and previous aggressiveness 
in each sample. Those who played a lot of violent video games became 
relatively more physically aggressive. Multisample structure equation 
modeling revealed that this longitudinal effect was of a similar magnitude 
in the United States and Japan for similar-aged youth and was smaller (but 
still significant) in the sample that included older youth…. These 
longitudinal results confirm earlier experimental and cross-sectional 
studies that had suggested that playing violent video games is a 
significant risk factor for later physically aggressive behavior and that 
this violent video game effect on youth generalizes across very different 
cultures. As a whole, the research strongly suggests reducing the exposure 
of youth to this risk factor.”
- See more at: 
http://journalistsresource.org/studies/government/criminal-justice/value-violent-video-games-research-roundup#sthash.pUZaQJOL.dpuf
- 
“Violent Video Game Effects on Aggression, Empathy and Prosocial Behavior 
in Eastern and Western Countries: A Meta-Analytic Review” Anderson, Craig 
A.; Shibuya, Akiko; Ihori, Nobuko; Swing, Edward L.; Bushman, Brad J.; 
Sakamoto, Akira; Rothstein, Hannah R.; Saleem, Muniba. Psychological 
Bulletin, March 2010, Vol. 136(2), 151-173.
Abstract: “Meta-analytic procedures were used to test the effects of 
violent video games on aggressive behavior, aggressive cognition, 
aggressive affect, physiological arousal, empathy/desensitization, and 
prosocial behavior. Unique features of this meta-analytic review include 
(a) more restrictive methodological quality inclusion criteria than in past 
meta-analyses; (b) cross-cultural comparisons; (c) longitudinal studies for 
all outcomes except physiological arousal; (d) conservative statistical 
controls; (e) multiple moderator analyses; and (f) sensitivity analyses. 
Social-cognitive models and cultural differences between Japan and Western 
countries were used to generate theory-based predictions. Meta-analyses 
yielded significant effects for all 6 outcome variables. The pattern of 
results for different outcomes and research designs (experimental, 
cross-sectional, longitudinal) fit theoretical predictions well. The 
evidence strongly suggests that exposure to violent video games is a causal 
risk factor for increased aggressive behavior, aggressive cognition, and 
aggressive affect and for decreased empathy and prosocial behavior. 
Moderator analyses revealed significant research design effects, weak 
evidence of cultural differences in susceptibility and type of measurement 
effects, and no evidence of sex differences in susceptibility. Results of 
various sensitivity analyses revealed these effects to be robust, with 
little evidence of selection (publication) bias.”
- See more at: 
http://journalistsresource.org/studies/government/criminal-justice/value-violent-video-games-research-roundup#sthash.pUZaQJOL.dpuf

+Karl Nordgren Sorry I didn't see this until now. I actually get what 
you're saying and, in fact, I'm a big supporter of Children's Rights, 
myself.

The thing is, I'm not sure you really got what I was trying to say. If 
feminists actually succeed in tearing down the kyriarchy (the larger 
structure of which patriarchy is a part), it's not just women who stand to 
gain from that, but *everyone* (people of color, cis men, trans men, trans 
women, children, the disabled, homosexuals, etc).

I'm taking an Introduction to Evolutionary Psychology right now, and I 
definitely agree and accept that there's a lot to be said for trying to 
understand the origins of human behavior. I myself am a firm believer that 
there is nothing truly unique to the human animal other than the scale at 
which we do things, and it is through that lens that I am trying to 
understand fanaticism (I'm majoring in Anthropology and will probably go on 
to get a degree in Evo Psych for this purpose). The problem is when the 
findings of Evolutionary Psychology are used to *justify* social inequality.

Women evolved to be child-bearers while men didn't, so yes, there will be 
differences in the evolutionary make-up of men and women. This does not 
justify victim-blaming, men getting harder/more dangerous jobs, women 
making less than men, and the general treatment of women as inferior to 
men. No amount of Evo Psych in the world will justify someone blaming a 
rape victim for getting raped. And frankly, Evo-Psych explanations of 
gender differences tend to be very heteronormative, in that they largely 
ignore the existence of people on the LGBTQA spectrum (that is, lesbians, 
gays, bisexuals, trans*, queers, asexuals, etc). And while Evo-Psych 
explanations of gender differences ignore these people, they cannot be 
good, comprehensive explanations.

Think of it this way: as a scientific explanation for the origins of the 
complexity of life on earth, Neodarwinism is basically perfect (albeit as 
far as a scientific theory can be perfect). The Theory of Evolution remains 
unchallenged in this area. But what happens when you try to use the Theory 
of Evolution to build a society? Social Darwinism, and even *Richard 
Dawkins* is a virulent anti-Social Darwinist... in fact, it would not 
surprise me to find that Charles Darwin himself would have major issues 
with the idea of Social Darwinism.

Science cannot inform the social structure of a society, nor can it be used 
to justify inherent societal inequalities. Science is simply the best tool 
we have to understand the nature of reality, so it can *explain* these 
things... just not *justify* them. That doesn't mean we shouldn't strive to 
fight social injustices. Feminists (at least the ones I ally myself with) 
are doing just that. In reality, the feminism I subscribe to is very much 
in agreement with MRM grievances *put on paper*, which is why I say, again, 
that if MRAs actually *did* care about the ways in which society negatively 
affects men, they would be feminists, or at least allies, working to tear 
down the same social systems that hurt women, because they are the same 
social systems hurting men, as well.

+JacobTefft argument from authority tends is not an all encompassing 
fallacy that includes any authority on a subject who speaks on the subject. 
Her authority is backed by her empiric findings. Appeal to authority only 
is a valid call when the authority is being believed unquestioned and 
without needing to support , or when it is fairly obvious that it is false 
but their authority causes people to nonetheless accept it (see Dr. Oz for 
a good example of appeal to authority in action, even when what he says 
isn't complete bullcheese , people believe it because he said it and that 
some).

That said a necessary criteria for appeal to authority is the individual 
and group acceptance of an authority figure, in her case this isn't really 
prevalent and many who accept her claims do so because we've investigated 
further using empirical data and not opinion pieces like the SJW core loves 
to cite, when not citing made up statistics.

+JacobTefft

So it's valid when it's Anita Sarkeesian but it's invalid when it's Sommers.

Before you sell your argument, you must first sell yourself, and you 
typically do that by listing your accomplishments.  You establish your 
authority to compel a listening audience.

The argument from authority fallacy merely states that not everything that 
comes out of their mouth is gospel and must be fact checked, something you 
can do with Sommers and not Sarkeesian.

The way you utilized it suggests that just because she is something doesn't 
mean she's worth listening to, which is ignorance.
+JacobTefft Which is actually a valid argument when used properly.

1. What's wrong with asking more than one question? Why can't someone 
discuss more than one idea?
2. No, she doesn't answer it. Did she say she would? At the end, she asks 
the viewer what they think of this controversy, suggesting it's meant to be 
an open question.
3. Sexism should, in theory, create a hostile environment for women. As 
such, the number of women that play games would likely be linked to this. 
It's reasonable to request more relevant data, but this does address sexism.
3.1. You may say that sexism would not deter women from playing games, and 
that people will consume media that degrades them. If you think this to be 
the case, the it seems that you think women, and to some extent, people in 
general, to be stupid, or lacking in self respect. I would argue that such 
a point of view is sexist, and perhaps even misanthropic.
4. Mentioning two things together doesn't conflate them. Asking if you like 
fish and chips doesn't imply that they are the same, or similar, just that 
they go together. Since misogyny and violence are the to most major 
criticism of games in the public eye, the do go together. This is made 
clear when, after mentioning criticism over violence, she then mentions a 
*new* wave of critics, then mentioning misogyny. This creates a clear 
distinction.
5. Again, why can't a video mention more than one thing? Violence was the 
old (though it's not gone) criticism of games, sexism is the new one. 
Exploration of the former is useful for comparison to the latter.
6. It's not an ad hominem if it's not a substitute for an actual argument. 
Insulting someone (which that barely even was, btw) and then making your 
argument is in no way fallacious.
7. Why point them out? The video is clearly a general response.
8. A few? If you limit it to protagonists, yeah, but that seems kind of 
arbitrary. Plenty of games portray a diverse range of characters, including 
females. Is it misogynistic that they're mostly male? I'll address that in 
point 11.
8.1. This also ignores the number of settings in which it makes sense that 
there would be no women, or at least none active, as well as the ones in 
which the player character is generic, as are the enemies, and the lack of 
females is merely to save on character models and voices.
9. Just about their boobs? Most of the time, it's your decision to see 
these characters as *just* about their boobs. They have other personality 
traits that you choose to ignore in order to benefit your own views.
9.1. Why is it an issue when female characters are sexualized? What is the 
issue with enjoying a woman's body? Later, you claim that nobody said it 
makes you sexist, so what is the negative effect? The most common response 
is that it portrays sexism, but I don't see how it's sexist. Even if you 
want to class these characters as sex objects, (which is often a gross 
mischaracterization, and as mentioned above, your choice), so what? 
Literally every character in video games is an object for your 
entertainment. Why is this special?
10. I don't agree that they are full of sexist tropes. At least not played 
straight. Most of the examples I've seen are deliberate attempts to read 
sexism into games where they don't exist. i.e. Anita Sarkeesian read the 
sexism into the scene in Watch_Dogs where you rescue women being sex 
trafficked. You were saving them from criminals; them being on display was 
clearly meant to evoke disgust. It's clearly a message against the 
exploitation of women. That's not sexist.
11. Catering to a demographic is sexist? How? How is it sexist to let 
people do what they want? Look at hidden object games, which contain mostly 
female protagonists. Why? Because mostly women play them. Is that sexist? I 
don't think so. Like 11, it's just playing to your demographic. You can't 
come to a business as a minority, and expect equal supply, as you don't 
generate equal demand. Demand is proportionate to supply.
11.1. Equating what she said to "video games are sexist, and boys will be 
boys" is a straw man. Please explain how her statement leads to that.
12. Fair enough, nobody said that. Even as someone who opposes your side of 
the argument, I have to admit, that point irks me, as it is an assumption 
of your position.
13. How is it false equivalence? The first thing that comes to mind as a 
possible answer is that Oprah isn't the entirety, or majority, of 
mainstream television. Neither are AAA games. Casual games are huge, and 
indie games are a lot bigger than they used to be. See the hidden object 
game example in 11.
14. Congratulations, you found hate on the internet. You can do that for 
any group. Muslims, Christians, Jews, black people, white people, and even 
feminists. Just look at the KYM photo list for gamergate for that. Would 
you use those to imply anything negative about those groups?
And before you call any/all of those isolated incidents, please explain why 
the examples you gave were not.﻿

I feel like you're conflating the idea of having a particular 
position/perspective/critical methodology with that of having an ulterior 
agenda, which isn't really fair. I'm not an expert on the guy, but my 
understanding is that Jack Thompson's agenda was to ban and censor all 
sorts of media that he objected to (and, not incidentally, sue the 
publishers for millions). Sarkeesian, meanwhile, is a feminist media 
critic, and her 'agenda' seems to be to, well, produce feminist criticism 
of media. Anyway, regardless of whatever agenda a critic may or may not 
have, the important thing is the strength of the criticism itself.

"I'm all for the criticizing of games, IF the games content lends itself to 
the topic of discussion/ire(I.E.: Its reasonable to discuss the politics of 
games that weave political commentary into the plot, but it would be 
asinine to discuss the political implications of Pacman as its plot is just 
a paper thin and superficial excuse for the events/gameplay of the game to 
occur.)"

I completely disagree: finding broader cultural meaning and political 
subtext in places where it might not be initially apparent is one of the 
things that good criticism does. I think that actually, a lot of the best 
criticism comes about when critics focus on media that wasn't meant to be 
especially provocative or thoughtful - you learn a lot about a society by 
looking at what it goes to for simple entertainment.

"She also cited Double Dragon for its use of the Damsel in Distress trope, 
when in the games ending, the Damsel incapacitates the main villain (in a 
sense to say, I am strong and I didn't need you to save me) essentially 
subverting the trope."

I'm not sure how fruitful it is to argue over one of Sarkeesian's examples, 
since a big part of her approach is to show many examples of a given trope, 
but I'd like to discuss this one... Again, I'm not an expert (I've only 
played a few of the Double Dragon games), but my understanding is: In her 
video, Sarkeesian shows footage from seven Double Dragon games released 
over the course of more than 20 years, and in all of them you see women 
getting beaten and kidnapped; she doesn't show that in one of these games 
(the most recent?) there's also a moment where one of the kidnapped women 
kills (or at least stops) the bad guy. I really don't think that this one, 
subversive moment somehow negates the other ways that the series has 
indulged in this particular trope, and it's also not even much of a 
subversion within the one game, since the character still needs to be 
rescued by the male protagonist (right?).

"My final gripe with Anita is her absolute aversion to debate. Everyone 
with a differing opinion (myself included) are label misogynists."

Has she actually said this? My sense of it is that she's open to civil 
debate and disagreement. I think that when she talks about the misogynists 
unfairly attacking her, she doesn't mean everyone who disagrees - she means 
the misogynists who've been unfairly attacking her (of which there've been 
plenty).

I'm gonna go ahead and 100% disagree with you, here. For example, the works

important concepts in the mediums they were investigating, and also because

not a necessary component of good criticism - critics aren't 
schoolteachers, after all.

To the OP: You're forgetting that critics actually do play an important 
role in helping to establish, define and evolve creative forms. Clement 
Greenberg is a major figure in the history of abstract painting; Pauline 
Kael is a major figure in the film world; Susan Sontag had a big influence 
on the development of photography as an art form; etc. etc. You could argue 
that great critics don't have the same degree of influence as great 
artists, but it would be silly to dismiss the importance of criticism 
entirely.

+TheBrentagon *"…Because the word "sexist" implies someone who explicitly 
discriminates based on gender."*

There's no implication. Sexism is *explicitly* defined as discrimination 
based on gender.

*"If your definition of sexism is just "negative perceptions or beliefs of 
any sort about a particular gender", then that would mean that almost 
literally everybody could be labelled "a sexist"."*

It doesn't matter how many people believe something. If a person views 
another or believes them to be in some negative light *because of their 
gender* (notice the emphasis on "because of their gender"), then it is 
sexism. This isn't *my* definition. It's based on reason. I'm not defining 
or redefining anything.

*"I believe either her or her co-writer mentioned on Twitter recently, that 
it's not really all that helpful to label individual people as sexists."*

If they did, then it would be a blatant hypocrisy, because she explicitly 
throws the word "sexist" and "misogyny" at developers of games like Grand 
Theft Auto and Fat Princess.

*"It's just that people happen to take on cultural beliefs, and some of 
those cultural beliefs happen to be sexist or have sexist implications."*

And her position is that some video games contribute to that, which is 
based on mere assumption, tenuous evidence, and/or misinterpreting studies. *That's 
the big problem.*

*"I am saying that debating whether or not "video games cause sexism" is 
pointless because it's such a nebulous idea to even define."*

I agree, and that's what makes her Tropes vs. Women in Video Games series 
completely pointless. She wasted almost $160,000 in donations to make a 
shitty web series made of almost complete hypocrisy, bias, opinion, lies, 
and misinformation for educational purposes. Sure, once in a while she 
might have a good point (e.g. the creation of Ms. Pac Man being akin to 
Adam and Eve), but it's rare. This is absolutely unacceptable to present on 
*any* academic level.

*"If one person interprets it as "video games brainwash you into hating 
women", and the other believes "video games are pieces of media which, like 
all media, contribute to society wide culturally fuelled beliefs about 
gender roles and sexual politics", then the two people are going to just be 
talking past each other and won't be able to have a meaningful 
conversation... Even if they technically are both talking about the same 
idea of "video games causing sexism".*

The former position is a straw man of the latter. The latter position is 
exactly what I'm seeing. The disagreement I have is that's not as "toxic" 
as she puts it, and if it somehow *is*, then the piece of media doesn't 
have to change. An entertainer's and artist's job is simply that: to 
entertain. A news outlet's job is to inform as accurate as possible. It is 
*not* their responsibility to teach people what's right and what's wrong.

+TheBrentagon So if "causes sexism" can mean nearly *anything*, such as the 
examples you gave me, then how is "negatively impacts perceptions and 
beliefs about real world women" not the same? Sexism, by definition, is the 
discrimination on the basis of gender. If the types of images being 
criticized are negatively impacting perceptions and beliefs about real

discrimination because of their gender, and therefore *sexism*.

I don't think the right question to ask is whether or not video games 
instill sexism in the players. But, you can't really deny that the gaming 
community is infested with some rather sexist, racist, and homophobic 
ideologies. I'm not implying that this is the majority, no. But the level 
at which it's at right now is a pretty big margin that what you'd expect. I 
think the internet is to blame for most of this, because the internet gives 
someone the ability to do and say whatever they want with virtually no 
consequences in the outside world, which can be applied to online gaming. 
That said, some of the more reclusive denizens of the gaming community 
sometimes do not have a very positive outlook on people in general. It's a 
rather hard issue to tackle, as there is no real simple way to solve it 
without limiting freedom of speech. But, let's just hope that there's an 
uphill climb from this in the near future, or even the distant future. I 
don't think I'm overstepping my boundaries by saying that gaming should be 
fun for all involved, and not just fun at the expense of someone else.﻿

Clearly you have learned English recently. I mean how else could you 
completely fail to understand the words you insist on using. For instance I

You use the word "conflate" as though to imply that it is a negative thing. 
You see often people will combine ideas as a way to show that they are

cause specific negative behaviors they would not assume that if one 
behavior type is caused that no other behavior type is caused. In this case 
for those of us with a background in psychology specifically behavioral

sexism could not cause also violence or any other less complicated types of 
behavior. In fact it would be virtually impossible given all we know about 
the human brain and behavioral conditioning. Ah I see someone has taught

another person. See Anita Sarkeesian has a bachelors degree in 
Communications and a masters in Media Studies according to her Wikipedia 
neither of these in any way qualify her to be doing research or studies 
based off of these topics. She is quite literally as unqualified as it gets 
it would be like asking an astrophysicist to design the circuit for a 
computers motherboard. Ah you seem to have missed that the lady you are 
singing about has in fact stated a list of points. In the English language 
is is quite often common to list the items you are referring to before 
before making a point as to how they are related. Such as Hoffman listing 
issues that indeed may be sexist and definitely merit further research. Ah 
I see you must have thought she meant actually picking fruit when she 
referred to "cherry picking". This phrase is actually a colloquialism that 
refers to the mistake uneducated people tend to make when attempting to 
utilize the scientific method. It is unfortunately common for people just 
learning how science works to try and find pieces of evidence to prove 
their personal theory. However true science takes account of all the facts 
in order to find out what is actually occurring. Think of a match one could 
"cherry pick" that putting sulfur on the end of a stick of material would 
cause it to burn when struck and continue to burn until the material was 
mostly consumed. However in real science one would do experiments or make 
as many observations as they can and discover that indeed it only works 
that way with specific materials. I hope that helps. Feel free to message 
me if you want more in depth explanation of the term "cherry picking". Ah 
you see when Miss Sommers states that males will prefer games with strong 
male protagonists and sexy female characters is because they are males and 
you got that confused with the typical dismissive "boys will be boys" I can 
see your issue. You see in this country evolution is most often taught in

is in fact referring to more animal drives that are still in existence in 
both genders and continue to affect both genders to this day. I see you 
must have been taking a philosophy class in order to learn our wonderful 
language. You must not have fully understood False Equivalence. You see 
when she compared the criticisms leveled against one media with the 
imaginary criticisms against another form of media she was not intending to 
infer that those two are the same things. She was very clearly trying to 
point out how a reversal of genders might make the original seem silly. She 
was in fact not comparing Oprah to Video Games she was comparing the

research. This can be a difficult concept to wrap your head around but I

+fiveMIRrOrs

Well, there's the other issue: Every organization has the right to set its 
own rules. Whether a site allows free-for-all comments, like this one, or a 
restrictive zero-tolerance policy, like many forums, that is entirely 
within that site's rights. If you don't like the rules of whatever site it 
is with a zero-tolerance policy, then just go to another site with a 
free-for-all policy. Users cannot dictate to the owners what policies to 
set for their own sites.

+fiveMIRrOrs

Hate speech is just one form of restriction.

Another form of restriction is slander and defamation, which are restricted 
by the anti-defamation law: "English law allows actions for libel to be 
brought in the High Court for any published statements which are alleged to 
defame a named or identifiable individual in a manner which causes them 
loss in their trade or profession, or causes a reasonable person to think 
worse of him, her or them." In other words, spreading rumours and gossip 
aimed at destroying someone's reputation.

Yet another restriction is harassment, both verbal and non-verbal. In other 
words, calling someone a cunt or faggot isn't a problem in itself, but if 
they keep repeatedly sending someone hateful comments like that, to the 
extent that it can have a psychological effect, then it potentially becomes 
a criminal offence.

While freedom of speech should be protected at all costs, the moment those 
hateful comments aimed at an individual can actually harm that individual, 
physically or psychologically, then it can potentially become a criminal 
offence.

+fiveMIRrOrs

"Freedom of speech becomes before feelings, even if it allows anti-social 
behaviour."

That's incorrect. Making slanderous and derogatory comments about an 
individual is illegal in most developed countries and can lead to legal 
prosecution for defamation. Freedom of speech has limits, especially hate 
speech.

can't receive the funding to produce/master/mix the record in his own home, 
so Wintersun's new album has been stalled for months on end. Fans even

the money went straight to the vocalist/rhythm guitarist. Almost a failure,

I'm curious what the proposed solution would be. If you find video games to 
be sexist, how would you make them not sexist? From the arguments I've 
heard, if a female is portrayed as being sexy in a video game, that's 
sexist. If a female is there for sexual appeal, that's sexist. If a female 
is in dire need of help, that's sexist. If a female can be hurt in a video 
game, that's sexist. So, what do you propose? Should women in video games 
be forced to a strict dress code? Should sexual attractive (female) 
fictional characters be outlawed? Should we make all female video game 
characters invulnerable to all damage with god like powers? Honestly, what 
would your proposed solution be? How would you take a game that you find 
sexist, and alter it?

Look, these games appeal to a specific demographic. In an industry that is 
primarily male, more games will be tailored to men. It's great when a game 
comes along that breaks the mold, that furthers the industry, and expands 
the market, but you have to acknowledge that an industry will do it's best 
to appeal to the majority of its consumers. If 90% of consumers are of X 
demographic, while 10% are of Y demographic, you can expect around 90% of 
games tailored to X demographic. It would be ignorant and simply dishonest 
to state that the industry is immoral, biased, or prejudice, because the 
majority of the products don't appeal to my 10% demographic. You'd have to 
be incredibly selfish and self centered to demand that video games change 
to appeal to you, what you desire, and what you find, "appropriate." The 
fact of the matter is that video games do not make people violent. They do 
not make people sexist. They do not make people racist, bigoted, or the 
like, because they are fictional forms of entertainment. The vast majority 
of people can differentiate fact from fiction, reality from fantasy, and so 
on. There's an incredibly wide variety of video games out there. If you 
don't like certain ones, don't play them, don't financially support them, 
heck, even share your opinions on them, but the second someone starts using 
their subjective opinion to claim that certain games are objectively 
sexist, then I got a problem.﻿

So lets break this down shall we?

First comes the complaint that Sommers talks about two different topics 
which are separate.  Is there sexism in games and are women taking over 
games?  Well the studies she and Mann mention address the second point very 
clearly.  So for Mann to complain that she needs to cite different studies 
is a bit...odd.  Maybe he got confused in the catchy beat?

One of the key failing points is the context used in the song.  When the 
subject of misogyny and violence is brought up, Mann tries to separate them 
despite being intertwined.  This is in part due to the misuse of the word 
misogyny and the way it has been used heavily in the narrative lately.  It 
has since been a catchall phrase to defame someone rather than its original 
darker meaning.  But misogyny, real misogyny, is almost always associated 
with sexism and violence which are key components.  Whereas sexism doesn't 
need misogyny nor violence and is somewhat subjective.  So yeah that little 
part complaining why she's talking about violence when she is addressing a 
definition appropriately...well again I'm confused at your complaint.

Then there is the part where he acts in disbelief when Sommers makes the 
comment about wanting the male video game culture to die....yet that is 
what a slew of articles have headlined in the past month.  While he wants 
more choice, the majority don't necessarily agree if you look at some of 
those "sexist" titles and see how much money they make in relatively short 
periods of time.  GTA SA's "Hot Coffee" didn't become one of the most 
searched videos in Youtube because they were serving actual coffee.

Speaking of denial, Mann then breaks into the tune of "nobody said they 
made you sexist, racist, or homophobic.  And yet Sarkessian's videos (hey 
Anna) have done exactly by making a connection between sexism in gaming and 
sexual harassment/culture.  This has since been compounded even more by 
other authors who also attempt to link the two together.

False equivalence?  How so?  Oprah has been attacked by gender centered 
critics for the very fact that black males on her show were more often 
stereotyped as bad in some way.  She also spearheaded calls for men to 
change from being bad (harassers, wife beaters, etc) while throwing the 
rest of the male population out with the bathwater.  The comparison is 
uncanny.

Data?  Do you see that swipe at hipsters with degrees in cultural studies? 
That's coming from a person with an Ethics Ph.D directing disdain at laymen 
(persons) who try to do poor research. Hence the cherry picking comments 
she also makes. So about that data.  Well someone actually posted it.  
https://medium.com/@cainejw/the-factual-feminist-a-factcheck-f5ae584f56da

So basically you've made a song that is complaining that a video called "Is 
their sexism in games?" should have really been called "Is there sexism and 
misogyny in games?".  Either that or you wanted to focus strictly on sexism 
as a yes or no question which didn't need a video at all.

Catchy tune though.﻿

RE: >>Do you think that there is any amount of sexism in video-games? Do 
you think the damsel in distress trope is a good one? Do you think the

1. Is there 'some'? Yes.
2. Is the trope of a damsel in distress good? Yes & no.
3. Do I think the amount of 'scantily-clad' women in gaming is any cause 
for concern? No.

Every single video game picked out for showing some signs of sexism against 
women, anyone that's actually played those video games sees that either the 
male is portrayed as ultraviolent in those video games and/or the entire 
world it depicts as a portrayal of real life. At no point whatsoever, while 
the damsel in distress is always nearly-perfect (if-not-perfect), do we see 
a respect of portrayal to the male character.

Beside that, however, every video game aside from the sports & puzzle genre 
tells of a story (yes, that even includes Call of Duty). Someone has to 
actually write that story. No one just comes up and says, "oh hey guys, 
let's just do this and make her a damsel in distress since we know women 
can't fight for themselves."

Let's look at one game in particular, Grand Theft Auto. I lived within the 
metro-Atlanta ghetto for quite a few years (while my family was for several 
years longer before part of a criminal syndicate elsewhere) and there's no 
doubt to me those who would call GTA sexist haven't the slightest clue of 
how women are treated in the underground world.

Then look at Duke Nukem. From its first iteration up to Zero, it's called 
sexist. Why? Because it continues to portray a 1980s/90s-era alien 
invasion, which would in fact involve scantily-clad women dancing 
stripteasing about.

Then Mario? Like seriously? That's a Nintendo thing anyways. Just Nintendo 
milking off the younger generation as it always does.

Oh but what-about-what-about this or that <insert scantily clad chain 
bikini-wearing heroine>...? This is a considerably-overexaggerated 
contention. There's only one game that's really even worth mentioning, and 
that was Tera (maybe WoW I guess, I couldn't be bothered to play it for 
more than 15 seconds), while most other games are poorly-made Korean or 
Chinese F2P ripoffs that hardly anyone worth their money would play to 
begin with for dozens of other issues. Yes, many games like Skyrim have 
mods, but not only are mods user-created but those that ask nicely know 
there'll have mods for the other crowd all the same.

I don't even think Mass Effect was good for its customization. Offline, 
nothing beats Skyrim; online, it's between Aion, TESO, & Tera.

My only nitpick with the video is that people are indeed frequently making 
the argument that video games make people sexist. You can argue that 
there's a difference between contributing to a culture that has trivialized 
sexism and actually making people sexist, but at that point it's purely an 
issue of degree, so I don't think Sommers is really making a straw-man here 
(except for the racist/homophobic thing, which came out of nowhere). 
However, Sommers is wrong in saying there are no studies supporting the

Cherry-picking tweets of threats made against people is not the same as an 
interview. Or did you interview every single person whose tweet you quoted?
Furthermore, showing those tweets over her claims that gamers, in short, 
aren't sexist harassers, therefore implying that gamers *are*, in fact, 
sexist harassers, is rather dishonest. What do you know about these people? 
Do they even identify as gamers? 'cause if they don't, nothing they say is 
actually relevant to this discussion.

Also, you said that "Nobody said [games] made you sexist [...]", but let's 
just take Anita Sarkeesian's series "Tropes vs Women in Video Games" as an 
example. In the very first video, she says the following:
"[...]The Damsel in Distress trope [...] does help to normalize extremely 
toxic, patronizing and paternalistic attitudes about women."
Ignoring the fact that the usage of the word "normalize" isn't correct in 
this context, she's saying that games make sexist attitudes and opinions 
about women as a whole more acceptable to gamers. While this isn't quite 
the same as "they make gamers sexist", it isn't exactly a huge leap either.

And to ape your questions of "What points?", "What data?", "What gamers?", 
I'd like you to conclusively prove that "most AAA games are full of sexist 
tropes". And no cherry-picking, so I'd like you to look at all AAA games 
and show that the ones with sexist tropes make up over 50%. Only then will 
I accept your claim.
Mind you, I'm not saying that you're *wrong*. I'm just using your rhetoric.

Your response to her saying that "male gamers [...] evince a strong 
preference for games with male heroes and sexy women" didn't make much 
sense. You claim that that implies that "games are sexist".
How?
Just because it has a male hero? Or a sexy woman? That doesn't 
automatically make a game sexist. If the male characters in the game were 
strong, independent guys who don't take any shit from anyone and the female 
characters were weak, subservient and had basically no relevance beyond 
their sexiness, then yes, the game is sexist.
There's other ways for a piece of media to be sexist, of course, but just 
having a male hero and a sexy woman is *definitely* not enough, contrary to 
what you claimed.

Also, her last point that you addressed was that critics of gamers as a 
whole should stand down. To that, you say that you will not stand down, 
meaning that you'll... continue to criticize gamers? For what? For 
harassing people?
There's two important things wrong with this claim.

First of all, that the harassers were gamers.
Twitter accounts that harass these feminists usually get shut down rather 
quickly, so it's easier to look at their most inflammatory and vocal 
critics. Milo Yiannopoulos, for example, used the controversy surrounding 
Zoe Quinn and GamerGate to promote a very hateful anti-feminist agenda. 
From what I've been able to find, he is not a gamer and has never written 
about games before. I doubt he's the only non-gamer criticizing these 
people and saying that everyone who wrote these death threats and similar 
are gamers is plain wrong.
Of course, you're probably thinking "Cherry-picking!" to yourself, but that 
leads me to the second false conclusion.

Secondly, that these harassers are in some way representative of gamers as 
a whole.
I hope I don't have to point out how absolutely ludicrous this idea is. I'm 
willing to bet that most gamers aren't even aware of the controversy or of 
these feminist video game critics. I've asked some people that I know 
personally who play games regularly and are certainly enthusiastic about 
them. None of them knew what I was talking about.
From what I've been able to tell, most gamers who know about the 
controversy and the harassment are very much for inclusivity and strongly 
oppose harassment.

So, all in all, I don't quite understand the meaning of "We will not stand 
down." in response to what she said.
Unless you meant that you will continue to advocate less sexism, less 
harassment and having more games that approach issues in different, 
interesting ways?
If you meant *that*, then that's great! I'm all for that!
But it has *absolutely nothing* to do with what she said.

However, I do agree that the title of her video is rather misleading.
And that was *definitely* a Totally Sweet Guitar Break.﻿

People keep saying women are the majority in gaming now, but that couldn't 
be farther from the truth, unless you consider casual, mobile games in the 
equation. The studies that show women as a majority conveniently ignore 
game genre preferences, making them nothing short of useless as demographic 
targeting data.

Women game less (in total hours) than men:
http://psychology.wichita.edu/surl/usabilitynews/141/videogames.asp

They also gravitate more towards casual games

http://metro.co.uk/2013/09/14/casual-gamers-on-puzzle-apps-like-candy-crush-more-likely-to-be-women-study-shows-3992346/

http://www.flurry.com/blog/flurry-insights/mobile-gaming-females-beat-males-money-time-and-loyalty

Also, the WiiU has a 93% male presence on the eShop, and most WiiUs are 
online:

http://mynintendonews.com/2014/08/28/nintendo-reveals-demographics-of-wii-u-eshop-users-males-account-for-93-and-females-only-7/

Big publishers don't have an agenda to push women out of gaming. Their only 
concern is getting loads of cash - which kinda makes sense considering the 
unreal amount they spend on AAA titles, to the point where a million sales 
can be considered a failure. The reason why you see so many games in that 
portion of gaming w/o female main characters is pretty much a reflection of 
the links I showed before. They tend to stick to tried-and-true methods of 
making money. Their internal metrics also show this is the best way to 
proceed.

You want more games with female main characters? Buy more games that have 
female characters. You want better written characters? Buy more games that 
feature those. It really is that simple - just put your money where your 
mouth is. Should be easy for such a vast majority of gamers, right?﻿

It's art.  It's fucking art, that's what it is.  If you don't like the art, 
make some different art.  The solution is the same in any medium, 
particularly nowadays.  If you think the music sucks and that it should be 
doing something different, then get on your computer and make some music 
and show them how it's done.  No one is controlling charcoal pencils, or 
notebook paper, and no one is preventing /anyone/ from learning how to 
code, and making their own game.

Indy games and early access crowdfunded games are now a thing.  If there's 
such a hungry and untapped market for this game, then make the damned game 
and stop grandstanding.  If there's a thing that should be made, and 
there's a real lack of it in the industry, make the Social Justice Hero 
game, and show us there's interest there.  The industry will take notice 
that way. That's how you change things from the inside.  You and 
like-minded friends get together and make games that espouse your virtues, 
and we'll all see how much people enjoy playing them, and settle the issue 
for real.  You don't yell at other people for their games and tell them 
you'd like them to conform to a list of stylistic choices in the spirit of 
good taste and not 'triggering' anyone.

You do not get to change games by whining about the themes and costume 
choices inside of games in an effort to make people feel bad for the art 
they are making.  You can certainly criticize the art, you can call it 
unoriginal (which it often is), but when you criticize the game on a purely 
visual or "what it allows you to do" basis without actually /playing/ the 
game, no one can take your art criticism seriously.

Go make the game--your own art--yourself.  That's how you win.  Provide a 
visible alternative in the space, or else specifically give your Feminist 
Star of Approval seal on any games you like out there that don't violate 
your sensitivities.  Then we can see who shows up, and who might just be a 
bunch of really loud people making an uproar about a system that could be 
fixed by them actually making something.

Then the rest of us can just go back to worrying about buying games that 
are fun, and supporting people who make fun games.﻿

+Quigster23 "cater to the interests of certain groups of people (straight, 
white men) over other groups, and that's unequal and unfair"

   This is a generalization and actually racist too since you chose to 
include race in your opinion. You are assuming groups of people all share 
specific interests and have you chosen to speak for them. You know nothing 
about the people you are speaking for. Let them speak for themselves. If 
they exist, they have a mouth that they can use - and as shown by recent 
events they have chosen their sides and many are not behind the cause you 
believe in. They don't need you to speak for them anymore, they've done it 
and are still doing it themselves on both sides of the fence.
   On the race topic. Not all straight white guys like Gears of War. Not 
all black people dislike Gears of War. Same for homosexuals and every other 
group out there. You can't assume that all the people you speak for, 
without their permission, agree with you or even want you to speak for 
them. As the saying goes, "to assume is to make an ass out of u and me."

   As for it being unequal and unfair, those can be mutually exclusive. 
Just because something is unequal doesn't make it unfair, and vice versa. I 
think there is some inequality in games, but there is also inequality in 
the people who play games. Not every game can bow to every demand from 
every group. Some games should be made to be inclusive but those that 
aren't should not be pressured to conform to the standards of small but 
vocal groups that they never specifically intended to target.

   I think it's a shame that people don't get to represent themselves in 
gaming as much as they'd like but on the same note I'd like to point out 
that to a lot of people representing them self doesn't matter. I guess I'm 
kind of old when it comes to games, but more often I make a character and 
insert myself into their role instead of making a character and inserting 
my personality into them. I identify as bisexual, but if a game doesn't let 
me convey that then I don't think it's a huge issue - it's how they made 
the game after all and I respect their decision. If I dislike something in 
a game so much it bothers me personally I'll move on to another one.

   I think the assumption that people should have to change what they are 
making to appeal to larger or smaller groups is silly. A developer should 
be able to make anything they please for whoever they want without fear of 
being personally ridiculed for what he or she has made. When a developer 
changes what they've put in a game because of pressure from external groups 
that means their creativity is being pushed into a box of what is 
acceptable or not. They COULD stand by their decision - and be ridiculed, 
blacklisted, and even sent threats - or they could sacrifice their 
creativity to appeal to a large, hostile audience who wants it their way or 
not at all.

+Zach Woodruff The point a lot of people are making is that the video game 
industry, at least the AAA, tends to cater to the interests of certain 
groups of people (straight, white men) over other groups, and that's 
unequal and unfair. And that other groups don't have nearly as many choices
