And plenty of people complain about female representation in movies, which 
is also still very unequal. Perhaps you are just more in-tune with 
complaints about the video-game industry, because their is more of a 
slug-fest going on around it (but I'm not sure).

The video game industry has catered to hundreds of genres and intrests,

By your logic, if I don't like it when a crime happens, I should just

necessarily a crime, I'm just trying to illustrate a point).

The representation of people in media is a social justice issue. And issues 
of justice shouldn't just be ignored.

Generally, I'd say it's another issue of culture as a whole. I think we 
educate people relatively well (compared to sexism) about violence and 
crime. More people have understandings that these things are generally 
wrong, why they are wrong, and that violence and crime will lead you to 
being justifiably and suitably punished.

I think our society does a much poorer job of this with sexism, and 
say, rape. Our society is still very gendered, and our society does a lot 
to maintain these boundaries. People grow up with a lot of issues and 
confusion about the expectations of our gender, and society doesn't 
do enough to help with that. This contributes to a lot of awful, sexist 
behaviour, such as when men try to fulfill the whole macho-mode of 
masculinity that usually involves sexism.

When a game about violence shows up, then, a gamer can more easily separate 
themselves from it, because they have a better understanding of violence 
given to them by society. But because people are less informed about 
sexism, games that include sexist elements have more possibility to 
re-enforce bad ideas and behaviour.

This is largely just my critical thinking at play, and isn't backed up 
by say, a study, of course (as are most opinions about this topic, despite 
people's predisposition to judge everyone for not having hard evidence when 
it is convenient for them to do so).

"So, find some other studies to back up your claims"

You are essentially asking someone to prove an existential negative. The 
only claim she's making is that the claim of games leading to sexism and 
misogyny is baseless. This doesn't require proof as the burden of proof 
falls on the person making the existential claim in the first place. So, we 
ask again. What proof do you have for games leading to sexism and misogyny?

Hitchens' razor - "What can be asserted without evidence can be dismissed 
without evidence" or in more simple terms "The onus is on you to say why, 
the onus is not on the rest of us to say why not"

If, however, after reading this you still think you have a point (see the 
Dunning-Kruger effect), then please do me the courtesy of disproving the 
tooth fairy before replying.﻿

Sarkeesian uses examples, but Sommers uses validated data and research. 
That's a huge difference, because using examples does not tell us the 
proportion of an issue. This is why:

I can name ten examples of sexist games off the top of my head, but I also 
know there is an uncountable number of games out there. So it's not 
possible for me to measure the size of the issue. I can also name gamers I 
know in real life who are sexist, but I also know there's an uncountable 
number of gamers out there. So it's not possible for me to measure the size 
of that issue, either.

I can't measure the size of these issues because I'm acknowledging I don't 
have every piece of information I need to make those calculations—no one 
actually does.

You can't measure the size of those issues by your own guns, my friend. 
That's why we have researchers gathering information by examining thousands 
of people from a variety of ages, backgrounds, locations, etc. that you 
probably weren't aware of before, given that you're limited to observing 
your own little community or enviroment. Research is here to remedy that.

Examples aren't everything, they serve as an individual experience (which 
you can choose to trust or question). On the other hand, the goal of 
research is to shine light on a variety of experiences that you wouldn't 
have been aware of otherwise. Research is made to give you a greater world 
view.

Sarkeesian has her own true examples, but Sommers has thousands more with 
the power of research. That's why citing your sources is so important. ﻿

tropes aren't real gamers," or that "people making rape threats in Twitter 
aren't real gamers." 2) Their criticism is against ideas, not against

to be against the people criticizing the ideas. Responses like that seem to 
be more about "defending the tribe" than about responding to the criticism. 
They don't move the conversation forward.

There's a ton of "no true Scotsman" going around here. Don't like what 
someone says? They're "not a real gamer." Well, there's no simple rule to 
decide who's a "real gamer" and who isn't. Lots of good folks make and play 
games. Lots of shitty folks make and play games. Lots of usually-good folks 
who play games have certain shitty ideas. Lots of really great games have a 
couple shitty ideas built into them. Welcome to life: people are 
complicated.

If all you got from the criticism of sexism in games is "the video game 
industry sucks," I think you missed the point. The point is not to say that 
ALL of any group is sexist, or violent, or "bad." The point is to point out 
some of the shitty ideas that many game designers (a majority, let's be 
honest) use because "everybody else is doing it," or because "that's what 
sells." It's not an attack on people who love games. It's a defense by 
people who love games, but who hope for more great games without the shitty 
ideas.

It would be a lot more constructive if the people who think those ideas 
aren't actually problematic would have a real debate about whether they 
are, and not attack the people they disagree with or confuse attacking the 
idea with attacking the entire game that used it. You think they really 
should spend that $500K on boob physics rather than on developing more 
interesting side quests? Fine, please explain why.

are sex workers and/or scantily clad in real life, and there isn't anything 
inherently wrong with showing prostitution in games. However, when they're 
so commonly used as background decoration in an attempt to make a game 
gritter, edgier, and full of eye candy for a presumed heterosexual male 
audience, then it becomes pretty obvious that the industry (which, by the 
way, I'm a part of) has a problem. Criticizing the industry's lack of 
variety is not tantamount to censorship, and criticism is necessary to 
improve the medium.

+John Cynical If I could speak with the makers of Martyrs... I would

That aside, I'm not sure what equivalence you're seeing here. Martyrs was a 
story about women. Yes, horrible things happened to them, but it was their 
story. Hell even the primary villain was a woman. How is that in any way 
related to making women props and prizes in stories about men?  I mean I 
thought Martyrs was a deeply stupid movie, but I wouldn't call it sexist.

And how is the MPAA, a (seriously flawed, granted) private organization 
designed by the industry to police itself, anything like Sarkeesian? A 
censorship board, even a self-censorship board like the MPAA and ESRB, is 
not the same thing as a critic expressing an opinion. Self-censorship 
organizations exist specifically to protect the industry from crusaders 
like Fredrick Wertham or 1990s Joe Lieberman. Critics exist to inform 
consumers about the nature of a product they're consuming or interested in 
consuming.

So yeah? Sorry I couldn't give a more relevant answer to your question, but 
it's just not a very relevant question in the first place.
